section.title: User Interface
section.para: This section describes the different methods the user can use to create issues, edit issues, and query the database. We invision three main modes for interaction: command line, email, and web. However, based on the specification in the previous section, any mode may be added.

section.title: Command line
section.para: All &qmtrack; command-line functionality is accessed via the &qmtrack-cmd; command, using a command-line syntax popularized by the CVS program. The user provides a subcommand with each invocation of &qmtrack-cmd;, which specifies the type of operation to be performed. The user may specify options modifying &qmtrack;'s behavior, and, for certain subcommands, additional arguments.

When creating or modifying an issue, field values are specified as arguments. The user specifies field values to &qmtrack-cmd; commands using assignment notation, as in field=value. For set fields, different notation is used instead to add or remove elements from the set. To add elements, the user specifies field+=value. To remove elements, the -= symbol is used instead. All of the commands to create and edit issues use the above three operators to specify new values for fields. Alternately, you may specify the issue to be created or edited in its &xml; form as described in Section . If you choose to perform operations on the issue in this way, simply give the command and then, on stdin, give the &xml; of the issue to be created, edited, or queried on.

formalpara.para:
This command is used to create a new issue. It takes as its mandatory arguments a summary and categories. Optional arguments include any other field values you wish to set. For example,
&prompt;qmtrack create summary="My first issue" categories+=simple categories+=first iss2
will create a new issue that has the summary, "My first issue" and belongs to the two categories, "simple" and "first". The value printed is the ID of the new issue.

This command is used to edit an existing issue. It takes the ID of the command you wish to edit and then as arguments any fields you wish to edit. For example,
&prompt;qmtrack edit iss2 categories-=first iss2
will edit the issue with id "iss2" removing the category "first" from the issue. A new revision of the issue will be created and stored in the database. &qmtrack; responds with the issue id of the edited issue.

The split command splits one issue into two. The issue ids of the two new issues are printed (the old issue id is no longer used). For example,
&prompt;qmtrack split foo foo.1, foo.2

The join command joins two or more issues into a new issue. If any field assignments are specified, these fields are modified in the newly-joined issue. The issue id of the newly joined issue is printed. For example,
&prompt;qmtrack join foo bar foo_bar

This command is used to search the database for issues that match certain criteria. A Python-like syntax is used to specify queries, as described in . For example,
&prompt; qmtrack query 'front_end in categories and severity > serious' foo,bar,bar2,baz
searches for all issues in the category "front_end" at the severity level "serious" or greater. &qmtrack; responds with the issue ids of matching issues.

section.title: Output options
section.para: By default, &qmtrack; displays a comma-separated list of issue ids created, edited, or matched by the user's operation. Other output may be selected using the --format (-f) option. This option takes an option parameter, which is the name of a format style. See for parameter values.

row.entry: Issue ids, delimited with newlines, useful for shell and line-oriented processing.
Field assignments, in the format that would be passed to the qmtrack create command. Note that some fields, such as attachment fields, cannot be represented this way.

section.para: Additionally, the --custom-format (-F) option may be used to specify a different format. This option takes as its parameter a comma-separated list of field names to display in tabular format.

section.title: E-mail
section.para:
To create, edit, and query issues via e-mail, simply construct an e-mail with the command as you would issue it on the command line and send it to the database. The database will respond with the information in &xml; form. For example, to create a new issue, you can send an e-mail with this body:
create summary="My issue" categories+=foo categories+=bar
or with this body:
create <?xml version="1.0"?> <!DOCTYPE issue PUBLIC "-//Software Carpentry//DTD QMTrack V0.1//EN"> <issue> <field-data> <field name="summary">My issue</field> <field name="categories"> <item>foo</item> <item>bar</item> </field> </field-data> </issue>
Either way, you would receive an e-mail back containing the text:
<?xml version="1.0"?> <!DOCTYPE issue PUBLIC "-//Software Carpentry//DTD QMTrack V0.1//EN"> <issue> <iid>iss2</iid> <field-data> <field name="summary">My issue</field> <field name="categories"> <item>foo</item> <item>bar</item> </field> </field-data> </issue>
indicating that the issue has been created. To edit an issue, you may either give the command line for editing the issue or request that the issue be sent back to you for editing and subsequently send it back after you have edited it. For example, to remove the category, foo, from the issue we just created, you could send the following message:
edit iss2 categories-=foo
or you could send the following message:
edit iss2
with no arguments to the edit command except for the issue. Sending an email of this form will cause the database to send you the following message:
edit <?xml version="1.0"?> <!DOCTYPE issue PUBLIC "-//Software Carpentry//DTD QMTrack V0.1//EN"> <issue> <iid>iss2</iid> <field-data> <field name="summary">My issue</field> <field name="categories"> <item>foo</item> <item>bar</item> </field> </field-data> </issue>
which you would then edit to look like:
edit <?xml version="1.0"?> <!DOCTYPE issue PUBLIC "-//Software Carpentry//DTD QMTrack V0.1//EN"> <issue> <iid>iss2</iid> <field-data> <field name="summary">My issue</field> <field name="categories"> <item>bar</item> </field> </field-data> </issue>
(removing the category "foo") and send back to the database. If you wish to add an attachment to this revision of the issue, you can simply attach it to the email. In either case, you after the edit is complete, you would receive a message that looked like this: <?xml version="1.0"?> <!DOCTYPE issue PUBLIC "-//Software Carpentry//DTD QMTrack V0.1//EN"> <issue> <iid>iss2</iid> <field-data> <field name="summary">My issue</field> <field name="categories"> <item>bar</item> </field> </field-data> </issue>

As with creating and editing, you may also specify a query by sending an e-mail to the database. If you issue the command as is done on the command line, the syntax is identical to that on the command line. However, if you choose to use an &xml; representation for your query, you are more limited in the way you search. Imagine the following body of an e-mail message to be sent to the database:
query <?xml version="1.0"?> <!DOCTYPE issue PUBLIC "-//Software Carpentry//DTD QMTrack V0.1//EN"> <issue> <field-data> <field name="categories"> <item>bar</item> </field> </field-data> </issue>
This will return the &xml; representation for any issues that have bar in their category set. This would be equivalent to sending a message containing the body:
query 'bar in categories'
For more information about the query syntax that is allowed on the command line, see the section on .

section.title: Web
section.para: To create, edit, and perform queries on the web, the user will be presented with a form that has all the fields of an issue. This form will be generated by &dtml; using the special dtml-in tag that iterates over all the elements in a list (in this case, the fields of the issue). For more information about &dtml; and the dtml-in tag, see the &dtml; Reference manual. The &dtml; code to display the forms will be similar to the following: where for each field, the field name is displayed and then the method get_display is called on each field to determine the way the field should be displayed (e.g., as a text box, as a set of check boxes, etc.). For querying, another line is added to the above to extract from the field what choices for querying the user has (e.g., exact match versus substring match, less than versus greater than, etc.). Using &dtml;, the administrator will be able to specify headers and footers and other configuration-type information simply so the web interface looks and feels the way the administrator wishes.

shows the state model for the primary &qmtrack; web pages. Each state represents a web page.
The "New Issue Form" page displays controls for the fields in an issue, initially blank, to be filled out as a new issue entry.
The "Edit Form" page displays the same form, but with the fields populated with the current field values from an existing issue.
The "Query Form" page also displays a similar form, with the fields left blank; fields are filled in to specify the query. The "Query Form" also contains a control that can be used to enter more complicated Python expression queries.
The "View Issue" page shows the same form, but with non-editable controls displaying field values. This page has a sub-state in which the audit trail (revision history) for the issue is also displayed.
The "Issue List" page shows multiple issues resulting from a query in a summary format. The page also contains query controls, by which the query results may be refined with additional restrictions. This enables a "drill-down" model of browsing.
